verses.text: "The Lord grant unto him that he may find mercy of the Lord in that day".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:62
verses.text: He had compassion on me, he says, he shall therefore have the like return in that terrible Day, when we shall have need of much mercy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:63
verses.text: "The Lord grant him to find mercy from the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:64
verses.text: Are there two Lords then? By no means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:65
verses.text: But "to us there is one Lord Christ Jesus, and one God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:66
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:67
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:68
verses.text: ) Here those who are infected with the heresy of Marcion assail this expression; but let them learn that this mode of speech is not uncommon in Scripture; as when it is said, "The Lord said unto my Lord" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:69
verses.text: cx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:70
verses.text: ); and again, "I said unto the Lord, Thou art my Lord" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:71
verses.text: xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:72
verses.text: ); and, "The Lord rained fire from the Lord".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:73
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:74
verses.text: xix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:75
verses.text: ) This indicates that the Persons are of the same substance, not that there is a distinction of nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:76
verses.text: For we are not to understand that there are two substances differing from each other, but two Persons, each being of the same substance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:77
verses.text: Observe too, that he says, "The Lord grant him mercy".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:78
verses.text: For as he himself had obtained mercy from Onesiphorus, so he wished him to obtain the same from God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:79
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:80
verses.text: And if Onesiphorus, who exposed himself to danger, is saved by mercy, much more are we also saved by the same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:81
verses.text: For terrible indeed, terrible is that account, and such as needs great love for mankind, that we may not hear that awful sentence, "Depart from meI never knew you, ye that work iniquity" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:82
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:83
verses.text: ); or that fearful word, "Depart, ye cursed, into everlasting fire, prepared for the devil and his angels" (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:84
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:85
verses.text: ): that we may not hear, "Between us and you there is a great gulf fixed" (Luke xvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:86
verses.text: ): that we may not hear that voice full of horror, "Take him away, and cast him into outer darkness": that we may not hear those words full of terror, "Thou wicked and slothful servant".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:87
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:88
verses.text: xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:89
verses.text: , and xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:90
verses.text: ) For awful truly and terrible is that tribunal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:91
verses.text: And yet God is gracious and merciful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:92
verses.text: He is called a God "of mercies and a God of comfort" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:93
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:94
verses.text: ); good as none else is good, and kind, and gentle, and full of pity, Who "willeth not the death of a sinner, but that he should be converted and live".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:95
verses.text: (Ez.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:96
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:97
verses.text: ; xxxiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:98
verses.text: ) Whence then, whence is that Day so full of agony and anguish? A stream of fire is rolling before His face.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:99
verses.text: The books of our deeds are opened.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:100
verses.text: The day itself is burning as an oven, the angels are flying around, and many furnaces are prepared.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:101
verses.text: How then is He good and merciful, and full of lovingkindness to man? Even herein is He merciful, and He shows in these things the greatness of His lovingkindness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:102
verses.text: For He holds forth to us these terrors, that being constrained by them, we may be awakened to the desire of the kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:103
verses.text: And observe how, besides commending Onesiphorus, he specifies his kindness, "he oft refreshed me"; like a wearied wrestler overcome by heat, he refreshed and strengthened him in his tribulations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:104
verses.text: And in how many things he ministered to me at Ephesus, thou knowest very well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:105
verses.text: Not only at Ephesus, but here also he refreshed me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:106
verses.text: For such ought to be the conduct of one on the watch and awakened to good actions, not to work once, or twice, or thrice, but through the whole of life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:107
verses.text: For as our body is not fed once for all, and so provided with sustenance for a whole life, but needs also daily food, so in this too, godliness requires to be supported every day by good works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:108
verses.text: For we ourselves have need of great mercy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:109
verses.text: It is on account of our sins that God, the Friend of man, does all these things, not that He needs them Himself, but He does all for us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:110
verses.text: For therefore it is that He has revealed them all, and made them known to us, and not merely told us of them, but given us assurance of them by what He has done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:111
verses.text: Though He was worthy of credit upon His word only, that no one may think it is said hyperbolically, or in the way of threatening merely, we have further assurance by His works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:112
verses.text: How? By the punishments which He has inflicted both publicly and privately.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:113
verses.text: And that thou mayest learn by the very examples, at one time he punished Pharaoh, at another time He brought a flood of water upon the earth, and that utter destruction, and again at another time a flood of fire: and even now we see in many instances the wicked suffering vengeance, and punishments, which things are figures of Hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:114
verses.text: For lest we should slumber and be slothful, and forget His word, He awakens our minds by deeds; showing us, even here, courts of justice, judgment seats, and trials.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:115
verses.text: Is there then among men so great a regard for justice, and doth God, whose ordinance even these things are, make no account of it? Is this credible? In a house, in a market-place, there is a court of justice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:116
verses.text: The master daily sits in judgment upon his slaves, calls them to account for their offenses, punishes some and pardons others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:117
verses.text: In the country, the husbandman and his wife are daily at law.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:118
verses.text: In a ship, the master is judge, and in a camp the general over his soldiers, and everywhere one may see judicial proceedings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:119
verses.text: In trades, the master judges the learner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:120
verses.text: In short all, publicly and privately, are judges to one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:121
verses.text: In nothing is the consideration of justice overlooked, and all in every place give account of their actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:122
verses.text: And is the inquisition for justice here thus spread through cities, through houses, and among individuals; and is there no regard for what is justice there, where "the right hand of God is full of righteousness" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:123
verses.text: xlviii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:124
verses.text: ), and "His righteousness is as the mountains of God"? (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:125
verses.text: xxxvi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:126
verses.text: )  How is it then that God, "the righteous Judge, strong and patient" (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:127
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:128
verses.text: , Sept.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:129
verses.text: ), bears thus with men, and does not exact punishment? Here thou hast the cause, He is longsuffering, and thereby would lead thee to repentance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:130
verses.text: But if thou continuest in sin, thou "after thy hardness and impenitent heart treasurest up unto thyself wrath".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:131
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:132
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:133
verses.text: ) If then He is just, He repays according to desert, and does not overlook those who suffer wrongfully, but avenges them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:134
verses.text: For this is the part of one who is just.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:135
verses.text: If He is powerful, He requites after death, and at the Resurrection: for this belongs to him who is powerful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:136
verses.text: And if because He is longsuffering He bears with men, let us not be disturbed, nor ask, why He does not prosecute vengeance here? For if this were done, the whole human race before this would have been swept away, if every day He should call us to account for our transgressions, since there is not, there is not indeed, a single day pure from sin, but in something greater or less we offend; so that we should not one of us have arrived at our twentieth year, but for His great long-suffering, and His goodness, that grants us a longer space for repentance, that we may put off our past transgressions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:137
verses.text: Let each therefore, with an upright conscience, entering into a review of what he has done, and bringing his whole life before him, consider, whether he is not deserving of chastisements and punishments without number? And when he is indignant that some one, who has been guilty of many bad actions, escapes with impunity; let him consider his own faults, and his indignation will cease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:138
verses.text: For those crimes appear great, because they are in great and notorious matters; but if he will enquire into his own, he will perhaps find them more numerous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:139
verses.text: For to rob and to defraud is the same thing, whether it be done for gold or silver; since both proceed from the same mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:140
verses.text: He that will steal a little would not refuse to steal much, if it fell in his way; and that it does not, is not his own choice, but an accidental circumstance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:141
verses.text: A poor man, who robs a poorer, would not hesitate to rob the rich if he could.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:142
verses.text: His forbearance arises from weakness, and not from choice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:143
verses.text: Such an one, you say, is a ruler; and takes away the property of those who are under his rule.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:144
verses.text: And say, dost not thou steal? For tell me not that he steals talents, and you as many pence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:145
verses.text: In giving alms, some cast in gold, while the widow threw in two mites, yet she contributed not less than they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:146
verses.text: Wherefore? Because the intention is considered, and not the amount of the gift.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:147
verses.text: And then, in the case of alms, thou wilt have God judge thus, and wouldest, because of thy poverty, receive no less a reward for giving two mites than he who lays down many talents of gold? and is not the same rule applicable to wrongful dealings? How is this consistent? As she who contributed two mites was considered equal to the greatest givers, because of her good intention, so thou, who stealest two mites, art as culpable as those mightier robbers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:148
verses.text: Nay, if I may give utterance to something strange, thou art a worse robber than they.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:149
verses.text: For a man would be equally an adulterer, whether he committed the sin with the wife of a king, or of a poor man, or of a slave: since the offense is not judged by the quality of the persons, but by the wickedness of his will who commits it; so is it likewise in this case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:150
verses.text: Nay, I should call him who committed the sin with an inferior perhaps more guilty, than him who intrigued with the queen herself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:151
verses.text: For in this case, wealth, and beauty, and other attractions might be pleaded, none of which exist in the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:152
verses.text: Therefore the other is the worse adulterer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:153
verses.text: Again, he seems to me a more determined drunkard, who commits that excess with bad wine; so he is a worse defrauder, who does not despise small thefts; for he who commits great robberies, would perhaps not stoop to petty thefts, whereas he who steals little things would never forbear greater, therefore he is the greater thief of the two.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:154
verses.text: For how should he despise gold, who does not despise silver? So that when we accuse our rulers, let us recount our own faults, and we shall find ourselves more given to wrong and robbery than they; unless we judge of right and wrong rather by the act, than by the intention of the mind, as we ought to judge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:155
verses.text: If one should be convicted of having stolen the goods of a poor man, another those of a rich man, will they not both be punished alike? Is not a man equally a murderer, whether he murder a poor and deformed, or a rich and handsome, man? When therefore we say that such an one has seized upon another person's land, let us reflect upon our own faults, and then we shall not condemn other men, but we shall admire the longsuffering of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:156
verses.text: We shall not be indignant that judgment does not fall upon them, but we shall be more slow to commit wickedness ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 4:157
verses.text: For when we perceive ourselves liable to the same punishment, we shall no longer feel such discontent, and shall desist from offenses, and shall obtain the good things to come, through the grace and lovingkindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, to whom with the Father, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:1
verses.text: Homily IV.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:2
verses.text: Timothy ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:3
verses.text: "Thou therefore, my son, be strong in the grace that is in Christ Jesus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:4
verses.text: And the things that thou hast heard of me among many witnesses, the same commit thou to faithful men, who shall be able to teach others also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:5
verses.text: Thou therefore endure hardness, as a good soldier of Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:6
verses.text: No man that warreth entangleth himself with the affairs of this life; that he may please him who hath chosen him to be a soldier.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:7
verses.text: And if a man also strive for masteries, yet is he not crowned, except he strive lawfully.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:8
verses.text: The husbandman that laboreth must be first partaker of the fruits.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:9
verses.text: Consider what I say; and the Lord give thee understanding in all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:10
verses.text: The young sailor at sea is inspired with great confidence, if the Master of the ship has been preserved in a shipwreck.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:11
verses.text: For he will not consider that it is from his inexperience that he is exposed to the storm, but from the nature of things; and this has no little effect upon his mind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:12
verses.text: In war also the Captain, who sees his General wounded and recovered again, is much encouraged.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:13
verses.text: And thus it produces some consolation to the faithful, that the Apostle should have been exposed to great sufferings, and not rendered weak by the utmost of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:14
verses.text: And had it not been so, he would not have related his sufferings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:15
verses.text: For when Timothy heard, that he who possessed so great powers, who had conquered the whole world, is a prisoner, and afflicted, yet is not impatient, nor discontented upon the desertion of his friends; he, if ever exposed to the same sufferings himself, would not consider that it proceeded from human weakness, nor from the circumstance of his being a disciple, and inferior to Paul, since his teacher too suffered the like, but that all this happened from the natural course of things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:16
verses.text: For Paul himself did this, and related what had befallen him, that he might strengthen Timothy, and renew his courage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:17
verses.text: And he shows that it was for this reason he mentioned his trials and afflictions, in that he has added, "Thou, therefore, my son, be strong in the grace that is in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:18
verses.text: What sayest thou? Thou hast shaken us with terrors, thou hast told us that thou art in chains, in afflictions, that all have forsaken thee, and, as if thou hadst said thou hadst not suffered anything, nor been abandoned by any, thou addest, "Thou therefore, my son, be strong"?And justly too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:19
verses.text: For these things were to thy strengthening more than to his.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:20
verses.text: For if I, Paul, endure these things, much more oughtest thou to bear them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:21
verses.text: If the master, much more the disciple.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:22
verses.text: And this exhortation he introduces with much affection, calling him "son," and not only so, but "my son".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:23
verses.text: If thou art a son, he means, imitate thy father.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:24
verses.text: If thou art a son, be strong in consideration of the things which I have said, or rather be strong, not merely from what I have told you, but "of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:25
verses.text: "Be strong," he says, "in the grace that is in Christ Jesus"; that is, "through the grace of Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:26
verses.text: That is, stand firmly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:27
verses.text: Thou knowest the battle.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:28
verses.text: For elsewhere he says, "We wrestle not against flesh and blood".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:29
verses.text: (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:30
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:31
verses.text: ) And this he says not to depress but to excite them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:32
verses.text: Be sober therefore, he means, and watch, have the grace of the Lord coperating with thee, and aiding thee in thy contest, contribute thy own part with much alacrity and resolution.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:33
verses.text: "And the things that thou hast heard of me among many witnesses, the same commit thou to faithful men"; to "faithful" men, not to questioners nor to reasoners, to "faithful".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:34
verses.text: How faithful? Such as betray not the Gospel they should preach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:35
verses.text: "The things which thou hast heard," not which thou hast searched out.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:36
verses.text: For "faith cometh by hearing, and hearing by the word of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:37
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:38
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:39
verses.text: ) But wherefore, "among many witnesses"? As if he had said: Thou hast not heard in secret, nor apart, but in the presence of many, with all openness of speech.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:40
verses.text: Nor does he say, Tell, but "commit," as a treasure committed is deposited in safety.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:41
verses.text: Again he alarms his disciple, both from things above and things below.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:42
verses.text: But he says not only "commit to faithful men"; for of what advantage is it that one is faithful, if he is not able to convey his doctrine to others? when he does not indeed betray the faith; but does not render others faithful? The teacher therefore ought to have two qualities, to be both faithful, and apt to teach; wherefore he says, "who shall be able to teach others also".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:43
verses.text: "Thou therefore endure hardness as a good soldier of Jesus Christ".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:44
verses.text: Oh, how great a dignity is this, to be a soldier of Jesus Christ! Observe the kings on earth, how great an honor it is esteemed to serve under them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:45
verses.text: If therefore the soldier of the king ought to endure hardness, not to endure hardness is not the part of any soldier.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:46
verses.text: So that it behooves thee not to complain, if thou endurest hardness, for that is the part of a soldier; but to complain, if thou dost not endure hardness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:47
verses.text: "No man that warreth entangleth himself with the affairs of this life, that he may please him who hath chosen him to be a soldier.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:48
verses.text: And if a man also strive for masteries, yet is he not crowned except he strive lawfully".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:49
verses.text: These things are said indeed to Timothy, but through him they are addressed to every teacher and disciple.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:50
verses.text: Let no one therefore of those who hold the office of a Bishop disdain to hear these things, but let him be ashamed not to do them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:51
verses.text: "If any one strive for masteries," he says, "he is not crowned, except he strive lawfully".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:52
verses.text: What is meant by "lawfully"? It is not enough that he enters into the lists, that he is anointed, and even engages, unless he comply with all the laws of the exercise, with respect to diet, to temperance and sobriety, and all the rules of the wrestling school, unless, in short, he go through all that is befitting for a wrestler, he is not crowned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:53
verses.text: And observe the wisdom of Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:54
verses.text: He mentions wrestlers and soldiers, the one to prepare him for slaughter and blood, the other with reference to endurance, that he might bear everything with fortitude, and be ever in exercise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:55
verses.text: "The husbandman that laboreth must be first partaker of the fruits".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:56
verses.text: He had first spoken from his own example as a teacher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:57
verses.text: He now speaks from those that are more common, as wrestlers and soldiers, and in their case he sets before him the rewards.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:58
verses.text: First, that he may please him who hath chosen him to be a soldier; secondly, that he may be crowned; now he proposes a third example that more particularly suits himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:59
verses.text: For the instance of the soldier and the wrestler corresponds to those who are under rule, but that of the husbandman to the Teacher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:60
verses.text: (Strive) not as a soldier or a wrestler only, but as a husbandman too.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:61
verses.text: The husbandman takes care not of himself alone, but of the fruits of the earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:62
verses.text: That is, no little reward of his labors is enjoyed by the husbandman.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:63
verses.text: Here he both shows, that to God nothing is wanting, and that there is a reward for Teaching, which he shows by a common instance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:64
verses.text: As the husbandman, he says, does not labor without profit, but enjoys before others the fruits of his own toils, so is it fit that the teacher should do: either he means this, or he is speaking of the honor to be paid to teachers, but this is less consistent.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:65
verses.text: For why does he not say the husbandman simply, but him "that laboreth"? not only that worketh, but that is worn with toil? And here with reference to the delay of reward, that no one may be impatient, he says, thou reapest the fruit already, or there is a reward in the labor itself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:66
verses.text: When therefore he has set before him the examples of soldiers, of wrestlers, and husbandmen, and all figuratively, "No one," he says, "is crowned except he strive lawfully".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:67
verses.text: And having observed that "the husbandman who laboreth must first be partaker of the fruits," he adds,  "Consider what I say, and the Lord give thee understanding in all things".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:68
verses.text: It is on this account that he has spoken these things in proverb and parable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:69
verses.text: Then again to show his affectionate disposition, he ceases not to pray for him, as fearing for his own son, and he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:71
verses.text: "Remember that Jesus Christ, of the seed of David, was raised from the dead, according to my Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:72
verses.text: Wherein I suffer trouble as an evil-doer, even unto bonds".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:73
verses.text: On what account is this mentioned? It is directed chiefly against the heretics, at the same time to encourage Timothy, by showing the advantage of sufferings, since Christ, our Master, Himself overcame death by suffering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:74
verses.text: Remember this, he says, and thou wilt have sufficient comfort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:75
verses.text: "Remember that Jesus Christ, of the seed of David, was raised from the dead".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:76
verses.text: For upon that point many had already begun to subvert the dispensation, being ashamed at the immensity of God's love to mankind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:77
verses.text: For of such a nature are the benefits which God has conferred upon us, that men were ashamed to ascribe them to God, and could not believe He had so far condescended.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:78
verses.text: "According to my Gospel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:79
verses.text: Thus he everywhere speaks in his Epistles, saying "according to my Gospel," either because they were bound to believe him, or because there were some who preached "another Gospel".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:80
verses.text: (Gal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:81
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:82
verses.text: )  "Wherein I suffer trouble," he says, "as an evil-doer, even unto bonds".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:83
verses.text: Again he introduces consolation and encouragement from himself, and he prepares his hearer's mind with these two things; first, that he should know him to endure hardness; and, secondly, that he did not so but for a useful purpose, for in this case he will gain, in the other will even suffer harm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:84
verses.text: For what advantage is it, that you can show that a Teacher has exposed himself to hardship, but not for any useful purpose? But if it is for any benefit, if for the profit of those who are taught, then it is worthy of admiration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:85
verses.text: "But the word of God is not bound".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:86
verses.text: That is, if we were soldiers of this world, and waged an earthly warfare, the chains that confine our hands would avail.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:87
verses.text: But now God has made us such that nothing can subdue us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:88
verses.text: For our hands are bound, but not our tongue, since nothing can bind the tongue but cowardice and unbelief alone; and where these are not, though you fasten chains upon us, the preaching of the Gospel is not bound.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:89
verses.text: If indeed you bind a husbandman, you prevent his sowing, for he sows with his hand: but if you bind a Teacher, you hinder not the word, for it is sown with his tongue, not with his hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:90
verses.text: Our word therefore is not subjected to bonds.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:91
verses.text: For though we are bound, that is free, and runs its course.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:92
verses.text: How? Because though bound, behold, we preach.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:93
verses.text: This is for the encouragement of those that are free.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:94
verses.text: For if we that are bound preach, much more does it behoove you that are loose to do so.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:95
verses.text: You have heard that I suffer these things, as an evil-doer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:96
verses.text: Be not dejected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:97
verses.text: For it is a great wonder, that being bound I do the work of those that are free, that being bound I overcome all, that being bound I prevail over those that bound me.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:98
verses.text: For it is the word of God, not ours.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:99
verses.text: Human chains cannot bind the word of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:100
verses.text: "These things I suffer on account of the elect".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:101
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:102
verses.text: "Therefore I endure all things," he says, "for the elect's sake, that they may also obtain the salvation which is in Christ Jesus with eternal glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:103
verses.text: Behold another incentive.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:104
verses.text: I endure these things, he says, not for myself, but for the salvation of others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:105
verses.text: It was in my power to have lived free from danger; to have suffered none of these things, if I had consulted my own interest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:106
verses.text: On what account then do I suffer these things? For the good of others, that others may obtain eternal life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:107
verses.text: What then dost thou promise thyself? He has not said, simply on account of these particular persons; but "for the elect's sake".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:108
verses.text: If God has chosen them, it becomes us to suffer everything for their sakes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:109
verses.text: "That they also may obtain salvation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:110
verses.text: By saying, "they also," he means, as well as we.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:111
verses.text: For God hath chosen us also; and as God suffered for our sakes, so should we suffer for their sakes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:112
verses.text: Thus it is a matter of retribution, not of favor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:113
verses.text: On the part of God it was grace, for He having received no previous benefit, hath done us good: but on our parts it is retribution, we having previously received benefits from God, suffer for these, for whom we suffer, in order "that they may obtain salvation".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:114
verses.text: What sayest thou? What salvation? Art thou who wast not the author of salvation to thyself, but wast destroying thyself, art thou the author of salvation to others? Surely not, and therefore he adds, "salvation that is in Christ Jesus"; that which is truly salvation, "with eternal glory".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:115
verses.text: Present things are afflictive, but they are but on earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:116
verses.text: Present things are ignominious, but they are temporary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:117
verses.text: They are full of bitterness and pain; but they last only to-day and to-morrow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:118
verses.text: Such is not the nature of the good things, they are eternal, they are in heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:119
verses.text: That is true glory, this is dishonor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:120
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:121
verses.text: For observe, I pray, beloved, that is not glory which is on earth, the true glory is in heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:122
verses.text: But if any one would be glorified, let him be dishonored.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:123
verses.text: If he would obtain rest, let him suffer affliction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:124
verses.text: If any one would be forever illustrious, would enjoy pleasure, let him despise temporal things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:125
verses.text: And that dishonor is glory, and glory dishonor, let us now set before us to the best of our power, that we may see what is real glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:126
verses.text: It is not possible to be glorified upon earth; if thou wouldest be glorified, it must be through dishonor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:127
verses.text: And let us prove this in the examples of two persons, Nero and Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:128
verses.text: The one had the glory of this world, the other the dishonor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:129
verses.text: How? The first was a tyrant, had obtained great success, had raised many trophies, had wealth ever flowing in, numerous armies everywhere; he had the greater part of the world and the imperial city subject to his sway, the whole senate crouching to him, and his palace too was advancing with splendid show.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:130
verses.text: When he must be armed, he went forth arrayed in gold and precious stones.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:131
verses.text: When he was to sit still in peace, he sat clothed in robes of purple.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:132
verses.text: He was surrounded by numerous guards and attendants.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:133
verses.text: He was called Lord of land and sea, Emperor, Augustus, Caesar, King, and other such high-sounding names as implied flattery and courtship; and nothing was wanting that might tend to glory.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:134
verses.text: Even wise men and potentates and sovereigns trembled at him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:135
verses.text: For beside all this, he was said to be a cruel and violent man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:136
verses.text: He even wished to be thought a god, and he despised both all the idols, and the very God Who is over all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:137
verses.text: He was worshiped as a god.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:138
verses.text: What greater glory than this? Or rather what greater dishonor? ForI know not howmy tongue is carried away by the force of truth, and passes sentence before judgment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:139
verses.text: Meanwhile let us examine the matter according to the opinion of the multitude, and of unbelievers, and the estimation of flattery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:140
verses.text: What is greater in the common estimation of glory than to be reputed a god? It is indeed a great disgrace that any human being should be so mad, but for the present let us consider the matter according to the opinion of the multitude.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:141
verses.text: Nothing then was wanting to him, that contributes to human glory, but he was worshiped by all as a god.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:142
verses.text: Now in opposition to him, let us consider Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:143
verses.text: He was a Cilician, and the difference between Rome and Cilicia, all know.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:144
verses.text: He was a tent-maker, a poor man, unskilled in the wisdom of those without, knowing only the Hebrew tongue, a language despised by all, especially by the Italians.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:145
verses.text: For they do not so much despise the barbarian, the Greek, or any other tongue as the Syriac, and this has affinity with the Hebrew.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:146
verses.text: Nor wonder at this, for if they despised the Greek, which is so admirable and beautiful, much more the Hebrew.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:147
verses.text: He was a man that often lived in hunger, often went to bed without food, a man that was naked, and had not clothes to put on; "in cold, and nakedness," as he says of himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:148
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:149
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:150
verses.text: ) Nor was this all; but he was cast into prison at the command of Nero himself, and confined with robbers, with impostors, with grave-breakers, with murderers, and he was, as he himself says, scourged as a malefactor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:151
verses.text: Who then is the more illustrious? The name of the one the greater part have never heard of.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:152
verses.text: The other is daily celebrated by Greeks, and Barbarians, and Scythians, and those who inhabit the extremities of the earth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:153
verses.text: But let us not yet consider what is the case now, but even at that time who was the more illustrious, who the more glorious, he that was in chains, and dragged bound from prison, or he that was clothed in a purple robe, and walked forth from a palace? The prisoner certainly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:154
verses.text: For the other, who had armies at his command, and sat arrayed in purple, was not able to do what he would.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:155
verses.text: But the prisoner, that was like a malefactor, and in mean attire, could do everything with more authority.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:156
verses.text: How? The one said, "Do not disseminate the word of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:157
verses.text: The other said, "I cannot forbear; 'the word of God is not bound.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:158
verses.text: '" Thus the Cilician, the prisoner, the poor tent-maker, who lived in hunger, despised the Roman, rich as he was, and emperor, and ruling over all, who enriched so many thousands; and with all his armies he availed nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:159
verses.text: Who then was illustrious? who venerable? He that in chains was a conqueror, or he that in a purple robe was conquered? He that standing below, smote, or he that sitting above, was smitten? He that commanded and was despised, or he who was commanded and made no account of the commands? He who being alone was victorious, or he who with numerous armies was defeated? The king therefore so came off, that his prisoner triumphed over him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:160
verses.text: Tell me then on whose side you would be? For do not look to what comes afterwards, but to what was then their state.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:161
verses.text: Would you be on the side of Nero, or of Paul? I speak not according to the estimate of faith, for that is manifest; but according to the estimate of glory, and reverence, and preminence.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:162
verses.text: Any man of right understanding would say, on the side of Paul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:163
verses.text: For if to conquer is more illustrious than to be conquered, he is more glorious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:164
verses.text: And this is not yet much, that he conquered, but that being in so mean a state he conquered one in so exalted a condition.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:165
verses.text: For I say, and will not cease to repeat it, though bound with a chain, yet he smote him that was invested with a diadem.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:166
verses.text: Such is the power of Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:167
verses.text: The chain surpassed the kingly crown, and this apparel was shown more brilliant than that.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:168
verses.text: Clothed in filthy rags, as the inhabitant of a prison, he turned all eyes upon the chains that hung on him, rather than on the purple robe.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:169
verses.text: He stood on earth bound down and stooping low, and all left the tyrant mounted on a golden chariot to gaze on him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:170
verses.text: And well they might.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:171
verses.text: For it was customary to see a king with white horses, but it was a strange and unwonted sight to behold a prisoner conversing with a king with as much confidence as a king would converse with a pitiful and wretched slave.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:172
verses.text: The surrounding multitude were all slaves of the king, yet they admired not their lord, but him who was superior to their lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:173
verses.text: And he before whom all feared and trembled, was trampled upon by one solitary man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:174
verses.text: See then how great was the brightness of these very chains!  And what need to mention what followed after these things? The tomb of the one is nowhere to be seen; but the other lies in the royal city itself, in greater splendor than any king, even there where he conquered, where he raised his trophy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:175
verses.text: If mention is made of the one, it is with reproach, even among his kindred, for he is said to have been profligate.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:176
verses.text: But the memory of the other is everywhere accompanied with a good report, not among us only, but among his enemies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:177
verses.text: For when truth shines forth, it puts to shame even one's enemies, and if they admire him not for his faith, yet they admire him for his boldness and his manly freedom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:178
verses.text: The one is proclaimed by all mouths, as one that is crowned, the other is loaded with reproaches and accusations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:179
verses.text: Which then is the real splendor?  And yet I am but praising the lion for his talons, when I ought to be speaking of his real honors.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:180
verses.text: And what are these? Those in the heavens.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:181
verses.text: How will he come in a shining vesture with the King of Heaven! How will Nero stand then, mournful and dejected! And if what I say seems to thee incredible and ridiculous, thou art ridiculous for deriding that which is no subject for laughter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:182
verses.text: For if thou disbelievest the future, be convinced from what is past.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:183
verses.text: The season for being crowned is not yet come, and yet how great honor has the combatant gained! What honor then will he not obtain, when the Distributor of the prizes shall come! He was among foreigners, "a stranger and a sojourner" (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:184
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:185
verses.text: ), and thus is he admired: what good will he not enjoy, when he is amongst his own? Now "our life is hid with Christ in God" (Col.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:186
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:187
verses.text: ); yet he who is dead worketh more and is more honored than the living.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:188
verses.text: When that our life shall come, what will he not participate? What will he not attain?  On this account God made him enjoy these honors, not because he wanted them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:189
verses.text: For if when in the body he despised popular glory, much more will he despise it now that he is delivered from the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:190
verses.text: Nor only on this account has He caused him to enjoy honor, but that those who disbelieve the future may be convinced from the present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:191
verses.text: I say that when the Resurrection shall be, Paul will come with the King of Heaven, and will enjoy infinite blessings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:192
verses.text: But the unbeliever will not be convinced.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:193
verses.text: Let him believe then from the present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:194
verses.text: The tent-maker is more illustrious, more honored than the king.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:195
verses.text: No emperor of Rome ever enjoyed so great honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:196
verses.text: The emperor is cast out, and lies, no one knows where.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:197
verses.text: The tent-maker occupies the midst of the city, as if he were a king, and living.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:198
verses.text: From these things believe, even with respect to the future.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:199
verses.text: If he enjoys so great honor here, where he was persecuted and banished, what will he not be when he shall come hereafter? If when he was a tent-maker, he was so illustrious, what will he be when he shall come rivaling the beams of the sun? If in so much meanness he overcame such magnificence, to whom, at his coming, will he not be superior? Can we avoid the conclusion? Who is not moved by the fact, that a tent-maker became more honorable than the most honored of kings? If here things happen so beyond the course of nature, much more will it be so hereafter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:200
verses.text: If thou wilt not believe the future, O man, believe the present.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:201
verses.text: If thou wilt not believe invisible things, believe things that are seen: or rather believe things which are seen, for so thou wilt believe things which are invisible.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:202
verses.text: But if thou wilt not, we may fitly say with the Apostle, "We are pure from your blood" (Acts xx.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:203
verses.text: ): for we have testified to you of all things, and have left out nothing that we should have said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:204
verses.text: Blame yourselves therefore, and to yourselves will ye impute the punishment of Hell.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:205
verses.text: But let us, my beloved children, be imitators of Paul, not in his faith only, but in his life, that we may attain to heavenly glory, and trample upon that glory that is here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:206
verses.text: Let not any things present attract us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:207
verses.text: Let us despise visible things, that we may obtain heavenly things, or rather may through these obtain the others, but let it be our aim preeminently to obtain those, of which God grant that we may be all accounted worthy, through the grace and lovingkindness, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:208
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:209
verses.text: Timothy ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:210
verses.text: "It is a faithful saying: for if we be dead with Him, we shall also live with Him: if we suffer, we shall also reign with Him: if we deny Him, He also will deny us: if we believe not, yet He abideth faithful: He cannot deny Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:211
verses.text: Of these things put them in remembrance, charging them before the Lord, that they strive not about words to no profit, but to the subverting of the hearers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:212
verses.text: Many of the weaker sort of men give up the effort of faith, and do not endure the deferring of their hope.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:213
verses.text: They seek things present, and form from these their judgment of the future.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:214
verses.text: When therefore their lot here was death, torments, and chains, and yet he says, they shall come to eternal life, they would not have believed, but would have said, "What sayest thou? When I live, I die; and when I die, I live? Thou promisest nothing on earth, and dost thou give it in heaven? Little things thou dost not bestow; and dost thou offer great things?" That none therefore may argue thus, he places beyond doubt the proof of these things, laying it down beforehand already, and giving certain signs.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:215
verses.text: For, "remember," he says, "that Jesus Christ was raised from the dead"; that is, rose again after death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:216
verses.text: And now showing the same thing he says, "It is a faithful saying," that he who has attained a heavenly life, will attain eternal life also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:217
verses.text: Whence is it "faithful"? Because, he says, "If we be dead with Him, we shall also live with Him".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:218
verses.text: For say, shall we partake with Him in things laborious and painful; and shall we not in things beneficial? But not even a man would act thus, nor, if one had chosen to suffer affliction and death with him, would he refuse to him a share in his rest, if he had attained it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:219
verses.text: But how are we "dead with Him"? This death he means both of that in the Laver, and that in sufferings.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:220
verses.text: For he says, "Bearing about in the body the dying of the Lord Jesus" ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:221
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:222
verses.text: ); and, "We are buried with Him by baptism into death" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:223
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:224
verses.text: ); and, "Our old man is crucified with Him"; and, "We have been planted together in the likeness of His death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:225
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:226
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:228
verses.text: ) But he also speaks here of death by trials: and that more especially, for he was also suffering trials when he wrote it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:229
verses.text: And this is what he says, "If we have suffered death on His account, shall we not live on His account? This is not to be doubted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:230
verses.text: 'If we suffer, we shall also reign with Him,'" not absolutely, we shall reign, but "if we suffer," showing that it is not enough to die once, (the blessed man himself died daily,) but there was need of much patient endurance; and especially Timothy had need of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:231
verses.text: For tell me not, he says, of your first sufferings, but that you continue to suffer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:232
verses.text: Then on the other side he exhorts him, not from the good, but from the evil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:233
verses.text: For if wicked men were to partake of the same things, this would be no consolation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:234
verses.text: And if having endured they were to reign with Him, but not having endured were not indeed to reign with Him, but were to suffer no worse evil, though this were terrible, yet it would not be enough to affect most men with concern.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:235
verses.text: Wherefore he speaks of something more dreadful still.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:236
verses.text: If we deny Him, He will also deny us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:237
verses.text: So then there is a retribution not of good things only, but of the contrary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:238
verses.text: And consider what it is probable that he will suffer, who is denied in that kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:239
verses.text: "Whosoever shall deny Me, him will I also deny".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:240
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:241
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:242
verses.text: ) And the retribution is not equal, though it seems so expressed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:243
verses.text: For we who deny Him are men, but He who denies us is God; and how great is the distance between God and man, it is needless to say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:244
verses.text: Besides, we injure ourselves; Him we cannot injure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:245
verses.text: And to show this, he has added, "If we believe not, He abideth faithful: He cannot deny Himself": that is, if we believe not that He rose again, He is not injured by it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:246
verses.text: He is faithful and unshaken, whether we say so or not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:247
verses.text: If then He is not at all injured by our denying Him, it is for nothing else than for our benefit that He desires our confession.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:248
verses.text: For He abideth the same, whether we deny Him or not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:249
verses.text: He cannot deny Himself, that is, His own Being.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:250
verses.text: We may say that He is not; though such is not the fact.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:251
verses.text: It is not in His nature, it is not possible for Him not to be, that is, to go into nonentity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:252
verses.text: His subsistence always abides, always is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:253
verses.text: Let us not therefore be so affected, as if we could gratify or could injure Him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:254
verses.text: But lest any one should think that Timothy needed this advice, he has added,  "Of these things put them in remembrance, charging them before the Lord, that they strive not about words to no profit, but to the subverting of the hearers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:255
verses.text: It is an overawing thing to call God to witness what we say, for if no one would dare to set at nought the testimony of man when appealed to, much less when the appeal is to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:256
verses.text: If any one, for instance, entering into a contract, or making his will, chooses to call witnesses worthy of credit, would any transfer the things to those who are not included? Surely not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:257
verses.text: And even if he wishes it, yet fearing the credibility of the witnesses, he avoids it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:258
verses.text: What is "charging them before the Lord"? he calls God to witness both what was said, and what was done.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:259
verses.text: "That they strive not about words to no profit;" and not merely so, but "to the subverting of the hearers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:260
verses.text: Not only is there no gain from it, but much harm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:261
verses.text: "Of these things then put them in remembrance," and if they despise thee, God will judge them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:262
verses.text: But why does he admonish them not to strive about words? He knows that it is a dainty thing, and that the human soul is ever prone to contend and to dispute about words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:263
verses.text: To guard against this, he has not only charged them "not to strive about words," but to render his discourse more alarming, he adds, "to the subverting of the hearers".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:264
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:265
verses.text: "Study to show thyself approved unto God, a workman that needeth not to be ashamed, rightly dividing the word of truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:266
verses.text: Everywhere this "not being ashamed"! And why is he ever so careful to guard him against shame? Because it was natural for many to be ashamed both of Paul himself, as being a tent-maker, and of the preaching, since its teachers perished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:267
verses.text: For Christ had been crucified, himself was about to be beheaded, Peter was crucified with his head downwards, and these things they suffered from audacious and despicable men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:268
verses.text: Because such men were in power, he says, "Be not ashamed"; that is, fear not to do anything tending to godliness, though it be necessary to submit to slavery or any other suffering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:269
verses.text: For how does any one become approved? By being "a workman that needeth not to be ashamed".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:270
verses.text: As the workman is not ashamed of any work, so neither should he be ashamed who labors in the Gospel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:271
verses.text: He should submit to anything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:272
verses.text: "Rightly dividing the word of truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:273
verses.text: This he hath well said.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:274
verses.text: For many distort it, and pervert it in every way, and many additions are made to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:275
verses.text: He has not said directing it, but "rightly dividing," that is, cut away what is spurious, with much vehemence assail it, and extirpate it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:276
verses.text: With the sword of the Spirit cut off from your preaching, as from a thong, whatever is superfluous and foreign to it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:277
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:278
verses.text: "And shun profane novelties of speech".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:279
verses.text: For they will not stop there.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:280
verses.text: For when anything new has been introduced, it is ever producing innovations, and the error of him who has once left the safe harbor is infinite, and never stops.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:281
verses.text: "For they will increase unto more ungodliness," he says,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:282
verses.text: "And their word will eat as doth a canker".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:283
verses.text: It is an evil not to be restrained, not curable by any medicine, it destroys the whole frame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:284
verses.text: He shows that novelty of doctrine is a disease, and worse than a disease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:285
verses.text: And here he implies that they are incorrigible, and that they erred not weakly but willfully.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:286
verses.text: "Of whom is Hymeneus and Philetus,"  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:287
verses.text: "Who concerning the truth have erred, saying that the resurrection is past already, and overthrow the faith of some".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:288
verses.text: He has well said, "They will increase unto more ungodliness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:289
verses.text: For it appears indeed to be a solitary evil, but see what evils spring out of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:290
verses.text: For if the Resurrection is already past, not only do we suffer loss in being deprived of that great glory, but because judgment is taken away, and retribution also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:291
verses.text: For if the Resurrection is past, retribution also is past.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:292
verses.text: The good therefore have reaped persecutions and afflictions, and the wicked have not been punished, nay verily, they live in great pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:293
verses.text: It were better to say that there is no resurrection, than that it is already past.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:294
verses.text: "And overthrow," he says, "the faith of some".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:295
verses.text: "Of some," not of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:296
verses.text: For if there is no resurrection, faith is subverted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:297
verses.text: Our preaching is vain, nor is Christ risen; and if He is not risen, neither was He born, nor has He ascended into heaven.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:298
verses.text: Observe how this error, while it seems to oppose the doctrine of the Resurrection, draws after it many other evils.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:299
verses.text: What then, says one, ought we to do nothing for those who are subverted?  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:300
verses.text: "Nevertheless," he says, "the foundation of God standeth sure, having this seal, The Lord knoweth them that are His.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:301
verses.text: And, Let every one that nameth the name of the Lord depart from iniquity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:302
verses.text: He shows that even before they were subverted, they were not firm.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:303
verses.text: For otherwise, they would not have been overthrown at the first attack, as Adam was firm before the commandment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:304
verses.text: For those who are fixed not only are not harmed through deceivers, but are even admired.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:305
verses.text: And he calls it "sure," and a "foundation"; so ought we to adhere to the faith; "having this seal, The Lord knoweth them that are His".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:306
verses.text: What is this? He has taken it from Deuteronomy; that is, Firm souls stand fixed and immovable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:307
verses.text: But whence are they manifest? From having these characters inscribed upon their actions, from their being known by God, and not perishing with the world, and from their departing from iniquity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:308
verses.text: "Let every one," he says, "that nameth the name of the Lord depart from iniquity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:309
verses.text: These are the distinguishing marks of the foundation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:310
verses.text: As a foundation is shown to be firm, and as letters are inscribed upon a stone that the letters may be significant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:311
verses.text: But these letters are shown by works, "Having," he says, "this seal" fixed thereon, "Let every one that nameth the name of the Lord depart from iniquity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:312
verses.text: Thus if any one is unrighteous, he is not of the foundation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:313
verses.text: So that this too is of the seal, not to do iniquity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:314
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:315
verses.text: Let us not therefore put off from us the royal seal and token, that we may not be of those who are not sealed, that we may not be unsound, that we may be firmly grounded, that we may be of the foundation, and not carried to and fro.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:316
verses.text: This marks them that are of God, that they depart from iniquity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:317
verses.text: For how can any one be of God Who is just, if he does iniquity, if by his works he opposes Him, if he insults Him by his misdeeds? Again we are speaking against injustice, and again we have many that are hostile to us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:318
verses.text: For this affection, like a tyrant, has seized upon the souls of all, and, what is worse, not by necessity nor violence, but by persuasion and gentle insinuation, and they are grateful for their slavery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:319
verses.text: And this is indeed the misery; for if they were held by constraint and not by love, they would soon depart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:320
verses.text: And whence is it, that a thing which is most bitter, appears to be sweet? whence is it that righteousness, which is a most sweet thing, becomes bitter? It is the fault of our senses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:321
verses.text: Thus some have thought honey bitter, and have taken with pleasure other things that were noxious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:322
verses.text: And the cause is not in the nature of things, but in the perverseness of the sufferers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:323
verses.text: The judging faculty of the soul is disordered.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:324
verses.text: Just as a balance, if its beam be unsteady, moves round, and does not show accurately the weight of things placed in it; so the soul, if it has not the beam of its own thoughts fixed, and firmly riveted to the law of God, being carried round and drawn down, will not be able to judge aright of actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:325
verses.text: For if any one will examine carefully, he will perceive the great bitterness of injustice, not to those who suffer it, but to those who practice it, and to these more than to the others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:326
verses.text: And let us not speak of things future, but for the present of things here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:327
verses.text: Hath it not battles, judgments, condemnation, ill will, abuse? what is more bitter than these? Hath it not enmities, and wars, and accusations? what is more bitter than these? Hath it not conscience continually scourging and gnawing us? If it were possible, I could wish to draw out from the body the soul of the unrighteous man, and you would see it pale and trembling, ashamed, hiding its head, anxiously fearful, and self-condemned.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:328
verses.text: For should we sink down into the very depths of wickedness, the judging faculty of the mind is not destroyed, but remains unbribed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:329
verses.text: And no one pursues injustice thinking it to be good, but he invents excuses, and has recourse to every artifice of words to shift off the accusation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:330
verses.text: But he cannot get it off his conscience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:331
verses.text: Here indeed the speciousness of words, the corruption of rulers, and multitudes of flatterers, is often able to throw justice into the shade, but within, the conscience has nothing of this sort, there are no flatterers there, no wealth to corrupt the judge.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:332
verses.text: For the faculty of judging is naturally implanted in us by God, and what comes from God cannot be so corrupted.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:333
verses.text: But uneasy slumbers, thick-coming fancies, and the frequent recollections of guilt, destroy our repose.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:334
verses.text: Has any one, for instance, unjustly deprived another of his house? not only is he that is robbed rendered unhappy, but the man who robbed him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:335
verses.text: If he is persuaded of a future judgment, (if indeed any one is so persuaded,) he groans exceedingly, and is in misery.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:336
verses.text: But if he believes not in futurity, yet he blushes for shame; or rather there is no man, whether Greek, Jew, or heretic, who is not afraid of a judgment to come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:337
verses.text: And although he is not a philosopher with respect to futurity; yet he fears and trembles at what may befall him here, lest he may have some retribution in his property, his children, his family, or his life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:338
verses.text: For many such visitations God inflicts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:339
verses.text: For since the doctrine of the Resurrection is not sufficient to bring all men to reason, He affords even here many proofs of His righteous judgment, and exhibits them to the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:340
verses.text: One who has gained wrongfully is without children, another falls in war, another is maimed in his body, another loses his son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:341
verses.text: He considers these things, on these his imagination dwells, and he lives in continual fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:342
verses.text: Know you not what the unrighteous suffer? Is there no bitterness in these things? And were there nothing of this sort, do not all condemn him, and hate and abhor him, and think him less rational than a beast, even those who are themselves unrighteous? For if they condemn themselves, much more do they condemn another, calling him rapacious, fraudulent, a pestilent fellow.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:343
verses.text: What pleasure then can he enjoy? He has only the heavier care and anxiety to preserve his gains, and the being more anxious and troubled.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:344
verses.text: For the more wealth any one gets about him, the more painful watchfulness does he store up for himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:345
verses.text: Then what are the curses of those whom he has wronged, their pleadings against him? And what, if sickness should befall him? For it is impossible for one, who has fallen into sickness, however atheistically he may be inclined, not to be anxious about these things, not to be thoughtful, when he is unable to do anything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:346
verses.text: For as long as we are here, the soul enjoying itself, does not tolerate painful thoughts: but when it is about to take its flight from the body, then a greater fear constrains it, as entering into the very portals of judgment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:347
verses.text: Even robbers, whilst they are in prison, live without fear, but when they are brought to the very curtain of the court, they sink with terror.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:348
verses.text: For when the fear of death is urgent, like a fire consuming all things besides, it obliges the soul to philosophize, and to take thought for futurity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:349
verses.text: The desire of wealth, the love of gain, and of bodily pleasures, no longer possesses it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:350
verses.text: These things passing away like clouds, leave the judging faculty clear, and grief entering in softens the hard heart.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:351
verses.text: For nothing is so opposite to philosophy, as a life of pleasure; nor, on the other hand, is anything so favorable to philosophy as affliction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:352
verses.text: Consider what the covetous man will then be.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:353
verses.text: For, "an hour of affliction," it is said, "maketh a man forget much pleasure".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:354
verses.text: (Ecclus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:355
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:356
verses.text: ) What will then be his state, when he considers those whom he has robbed, and injured, and defrauded, when he sees others reaping the fruits of his grasping, and himself going to pay the penalty? For it cannot, indeed it cannot be, that when fallen into sickness he should not reflect upon these things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:357
verses.text: For often the soul of itself is distracted with agony and terror.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:358
verses.text: What a bitterness is this, tell me! And with every sickness these things must be endured.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:359
verses.text: And what will he not suffer when he sees others punished or put to death?  These things await him here.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:360
verses.text: And as to what he must undergo hereafter, it is not possible to say what punishment, what vengeance, what torments, what racks are reserved for him There.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:361
verses.text: These things we declare.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:362
verses.text: "He that hath ears to hear, let him hear".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:363
verses.text: (Luke viii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:364
verses.text: ) We are for ever discoursing of these things, not willingly, but of necessity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:365
verses.text: For we could wish there were no obligation to mention such things at all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:366
verses.text: But since it must be, we would at least, by a little medicine, deliver you from your disease, and restore you to health.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:367
verses.text: But whilst you remain in this sickness, it would show a mean and weak spirit, not to say cruelty and inhumanity, to desist from the healing treatment.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:368
verses.text: For if when physicians despair of our bodies, we beseech them not to neglect us, not to cease to our last breath applying whatever is in their power, shall we not much more exhort ourselves? For perhaps when we have come to the very gates of Hell, the vestibule of wickedness itself, it may be possible to recover, to renew our strength, to lay hold on eternal life! How many, who have heard ten times and remained insensible, have afterwards at one hearing been converted! Or rather, not at one hearing; for though they seemed insensible at the ten discourses, yet they gained something, and afterwards showed all at once abundant fruit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:369
verses.text: For as a tree may receive ten strokes, and not fall; then afterwards be brought down all at once by a single blow: yet it is not done by that one blow, but by the ten which made that last successful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:370
verses.text: And this is known to him who sees the root, though he who takes his view of the trunk above knows it not.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:371
verses.text: So it is in this case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:372
verses.text: And thus often, when physicians have applied many remedies, no benefit is perceived; but afterwards some one comes in and effects an entire cure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:373
verses.text: Yet it is not the work of him alone, but of these who have already reduced the disorder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:374
verses.text: So that, if now we do not bring forth the fruits of hearing the word, yet hereafter we shall.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:375
verses.text: For that we shall bring them forth, I am fully persuaded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:376
