verses.text: For it is not, indeed it is not possible that such eager desire, such a love of hearing, should fail of its effect.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 5:377
verses.text: God forbid! But may we all, having become worthy of the admonitions of Christ, obtain the everlasting blessings, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:1
verses.text: Homily VI.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:2
verses.text: Timothy ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:3
verses.text: ,  "But in a great house there are not only vessels of gold and of silver, but also of wood and of earth; and some to honor, and some to dishonor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:4
verses.text: If a man therefore purge himself from these, he shall be a vessel unto honor, sanctified, and meet for the master's use, and prepared unto every good work".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:5
verses.text: Many men are still even now perplexed to account for the fact, that the wicked are suffered to remain, and are not yet destroyed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:6
verses.text: Now doubtless various reasons may be assigned for this, as, that they may be converted, or that by their punishment they may be made an example to the multitude.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:7
verses.text: But Paul here mentions a similar case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:8
verses.text: For he says,  "In a great house there are not only vessels of gold and silver, but also of wood and earth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:9
verses.text: Showing by this, that as in a great house it is likely there should be a great difference of vessels, so here also, in the whole world, for he speaks not of the Church only, but of the world at large.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:10
verses.text: For think not, I pray, that he means it of the Church; for there he would not have any vessels of wood or of earth, but all of gold or silver where is the body of Christ, where is that "pure virgin, without spot, or wrinkle, or any such thing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:11
verses.text: (Eph.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:12
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:13
verses.text: ) And this is what he means to say: Let it not disturb thee that there are corrupt and wicked men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:14
verses.text: For in a great house there are such vessels.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:15
verses.text: But what then? they do not receive the same honor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:16
verses.text: But some are to honor and some to dishonor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:17
verses.text: "Nay," says one, "in a house they may be of some use, but not at all in the world".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:18
verses.text: Though God employs them not for such honorable service, he makes use of them for other purposes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:19
verses.text: For instance, the vainglorious man builds much, so does the covetous man, the merchant, the tradesman, the magistrate; there are certain works in the world suited to these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:20
verses.text: But the golden vessel is not of such a nature.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:21
verses.text: It is employed about the royal table.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:22
verses.text: He does not say however that wickedness is a necessary thing, (for how should it be?) but that the wicked also have their work.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:23
verses.text: For if all were of gold or of silver, there would be no need of the viler sort.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:24
verses.text: For instance, if all were hardy, there would be no need of houses; if all were free from luxury, there would be no need of dainties.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:25
verses.text: If all were careful only for necessaries, there would be no need of splendid building.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:26
verses.text: "If therefore a man purge himself from these, he shall be a vessel unto honor, sanctified".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:27
verses.text: Seest thou that it is not of nature, nor of the necessity of matter, to be a vessel of gold or of earth, but of our own choice? For otherwise the earthen could not become gold, nor could the golden descend to the vileness of the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:28
verses.text: But in this case there is much change, and alteration of state.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:29
verses.text: Paul was an earthen vessel, and became a golden one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:30
verses.text: Judas was a golden vessel, and became an earthen one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:31
verses.text: The earthen vessels, therefore, are such from uncleanness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:32
verses.text: The fornicator and the covetous man become earthen vessels.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:33
verses.text: "But how then does he say elsewhere, 'We have this treasure in earthen vessels,' so that he does not despise but honor the earthen vessel, speaking of it as the recipient of the treasure?" There he shows the nature itself, and not the form of the material.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:34
verses.text: For he means to say that our body is an earthen vessel.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:35
verses.text: For as earthenware is nothing else but baked clay, so is our body nothing but clay consolidated by the heat of the soul; for that it is earthen, is evident.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:36
verses.text: For as such a vessel is often by falling broken and dashed to pieces, so our body falls and is dissolved by death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:37
verses.text: For how do our bones differs from a potsherd, hard and dry as they are? or our flesh from clay, being, like it, composed of water? But, as I said, how is it that he does not speak contemptuously of it? Because there he is discoursing of its nature, here of our choice.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:38
verses.text: "If a man," he says, "purge himself from these," not merely "cleanse," but "cleanse out," that is, cleanse himself perfectly, "he shall be a vessel unto honor, sanctified, and meet for the Master's use".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:39
verses.text: The others therefore are useless for any good purpose, though some use is made of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:40
verses.text: "And prepared unto every good work".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:41
verses.text: Even though he do it not, he is fit for it, and has a capacity for it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:42
verses.text: We ought therefore to be prepared for everything, even for death, for martyrdom, for a life of virginity, or for all these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:43
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:44
verses.text: "Flee also youthful lusts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:45
verses.text: Not only the lust of fornication, but every inordinate desire is a youthful lust.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:46
verses.text: Let the aged learn that they ought not to do the deeds of the youthful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:47
verses.text: If one be given to insolence, or a lover of power, of riches, of bodily pleasures, it is a youthful lust, and foolish.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:48
verses.text: These things must proceed from a heart not yet established, from a mind not deeply grounded, but in a wavering state.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:49
verses.text: What then does he advise in order that none may be captivated by these things? "Flee youthful" imaginations, but  "Follow righteousness, faith, charity, peace, with them that call on the Lord out of a pure heart".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:50
verses.text: He calls virtue in general, "righteousness": godliness of life, "faith, meekness, charity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:51
verses.text: What is meant by "those that call upon the Lord out of a pure heart"? It is as if he said, Rejoice not in those who only call upon the Lord; but those who call upon Him sincerely and unfeignedly, who have nothing of deceit about them, who approach Him in peace, who are not contentious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:52
verses.text: With these associate thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:53
verses.text: But with others be not easy, but only as far as lies in you, be peaceable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:54
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:55
verses.text: "But foolish and unlearned questions avoid, knowing that they do gender strifes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:56
verses.text: Do you see how he everywhere draws him off from questions; not that he was not able to overthrow them; for he was well able.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:57
verses.text: For had he not been able he would have said, Be diligent, that thou mayest be able to refute them; as when he says, "Give attendance to reading, for by so doing thou shalt both save thyself and them that hear thee".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:58
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:59
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:61
verses.text: ) But he knew that it was useless to enter at all into these disputes, that there will be no end of it, save contentions, enmities, insults, and reproaches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:62
verses.text: These "questions" therefore "avoid"; so that there are other questions, some relating to the Scriptures, some to other things.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:63
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:64
verses.text: "And the servant of the Lord must not strive".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:65
verses.text: Not even in questions ought he to strive, for the servant of the Lord must keep far from strife, since God is the God of peace, and what should the servant of the God of peace have to do with strife?  "But be gentle unto all men".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:66
verses.text: How is it then he says, "Rebuke with all authority" (Tit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:67
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:68
verses.text: ); and again, "Let no man despise thy youth" ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:69
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:70
verses.text: ): and again, "Rebuke them sharply"? (Tit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:71
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:72
verses.text: ) Because this is consistent with meekness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:73
verses.text: For a strong rebuke, if it be given with gentleness, is most likely to wound deeply: for it is possible, indeed it is, to touch more effectually by gentleness, than one overawes by boldness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:74
verses.text: "Apt to teach"; that is, those who are willing to be taught.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:75
verses.text: For "a man that is an heretic," he says, "after the first and second admonition reject".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:76
verses.text: (Tit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:77
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:78
verses.text: ) "Patient".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:79
verses.text: He has well added this, for it is a quality which a teacher above all things ought to possess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:80
verses.text: All things are vain without it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:81
verses.text: And if fishermen do not despair, though often they cast their nets for a whole day without catching anything, much more should not we.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:82
verses.text: For see what is the result.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:83
verses.text: From constant teaching, it often happens that the plow of the word, descending to the depth of the soul, roots out the evil passion that troubled it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:84
verses.text: For he that hears often will at length be affected.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:85
verses.text: A man cannot go on hearing continually without some effect being produced.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:86
verses.text: Sometimes therefore, when he was on the point of being persuaded, he is lost by our becoming weary.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:87
verses.text: For the same thing occurs, as if an unskillful husbandman should in the first year dig about the vine he had planted, and seeking to reap some fruit in the second year, and again in the third, and gathering nothing, should after three years despair, and in the fourth year, when he was about to receive the recompense of his labors, abandon his vine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:88
verses.text: And having said, "Patient," he is not satisfied, but goes on to say,  Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:89
verses.text: "In meekness instructing those that oppose themselves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:90
verses.text: For he that teaches must be especially careful to do it with meekness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:91
verses.text: For a soul that wishes to learn cannot gain any useful instruction from harshness and contention.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:92
verses.text: For when it would apply, being thus thrown into perplexity, it will learn nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:93
verses.text: He who would gain any useful knowledge ought above all things to be well disposed towards his teacher, and if this be not previously attained, nothing that is requisite or useful can be accomplished.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:94
verses.text: And no one can be well disposed towards him who is violent and overbearing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:95
verses.text: How is it then that he says, "A man that is an heretic, after the first and second admonition, reject"? He speaks there of one incorrigible, of one whom he knows to be diseased beyond the possibility of cure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:96
verses.text: "If God peradventure will give them repentance to the acknowledging of the truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:97
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:98
verses.text: "And that they may recover themselves out of the snare of the devil".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:99
verses.text: What he says amounts to this.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:100
verses.text: Perhaps there will be a reformation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:101
verses.text: Perhaps! for it is uncertain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:102
verses.text: So that we ought to withdraw only from those, of whom we can show plainly, and concerning whom we are fully persuaded, that whatever be done, they will not be reformed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:103
verses.text: "In meekness," he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:104
verses.text: In this temper, you see, we ought to address ourselves to those who are willing to learn, and never cease from conversing with them till we have come to the demonstration.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:105
verses.text: "Who are taken captive by him at his will".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:106
verses.text: It is truly said, "Who are taken captive," for meanwhile they float in error.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:107
verses.text: Observe here how he teaches to be humble-minded.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:108
verses.text: He has not said, if peradventure you should be able, but, "if peradventure God should grant them a recovery"; if anything be done, therefore, all is of the Lord.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:109
verses.text: Thou plantest, thou waterest but He soweth and maketh it produce fruit.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:110
verses.text: Let us not therefore be so affected, as if we ourselves wrought the persuasion, even if we should persuade any one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:111
verses.text: "Taken captive by him," he says, "to His will".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:112
verses.text: This no one will say relates to doctrine, but to life.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:113
verses.text: For "His will" is that we live rightly.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:114
verses.text: But some are in the snare of the devil by reason of their life, we ought not therefore to be weary even with respect to these.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:115
verses.text: "If peradventure," he says, "they may recover, that are taken captive, unto His will".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:116
verses.text: Now "If peradventure," implies much longsuffering.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:117
verses.text: For not to do the will of God is a snare of the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:118
verses.text: For as a sparrow, though it be not wholly enclosed, but only caught by the foot, is still under the power of him who set the snare; so though we be not wholly subverted, both in faith and life, but in life only, we are under the power of the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:119
verses.text: For "Not every one that saith unto me, Lord, Lord, shall enter into the kingdom of heaven"; and again, "I know you not; depart from me, ye that work iniquity".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:120
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:121
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:123
verses.text: ) You see there is no advantage from our faith, when our Lord knows us not: and to the virgins he says the same, "I know you not".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:124
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:125
verses.text: xxv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:126
verses.text: ) What then is the benefit of virginity, or of many labors, when the Lord knows us not? And in many places we find men not blamed for their faith, but punished for their evil life only; as elsewhere, not reproved for evil lives, but perishing for their pravity of doctrine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:127
verses.text: For these things hold together.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:128
verses.text: You see that when we do not the will of God, we are under the snare of the devil.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:129
verses.text: And often not only from a bad life, but from one defect, we enter into Hell, where there are not good qualities to counterbalance it, since the virgins were not accused of fornication or adultery, nor of envy or ill-will, nor of drunkenness, nor of unsound faith, but of a failure of oil, that is, they failed in almsgiving, for that is the oil meant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:130
verses.text: And those who were pronounced accursed in the words, "Depart from me, ye cursed, into everlasting fire," were not accused of any such crimes, but because they had not fed Christ.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:131
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:132
verses.text: Seest thou that a failure in alms-giving is enough to cast a man into hell fire? For where will he avail who does not give alms? Dost thou fast every day? So also did those virgins, but it availed them nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:133
verses.text: Dost thou pray? What of that? prayer without alms-giving is unfruitful, without that all things are unclean and unprofitable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:134
verses.text: The better part of virtue is destroyed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:135
verses.text: "He that loveth not his brother," it is said, "knoweth not God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:136
verses.text: ( John iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:137
verses.text: ) And how dost thou love him, when thou dost not even impart to him of these poor worthless things? Tell me, therefore, dost thou observe chastity? On what account? From fear of punishment? By no means.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:138
verses.text: It is of a natural endowment that thou observest it, since if thou wast chaste from fear of punishment, and didst violence to nature in submitting to so severe a rule, much more oughtest thou to do alms.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:139
verses.text: For to govern the desire of wealth, and of bodily pleasures, is not the same thing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:140
verses.text: The latter is much more difficult to restrain.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:141
verses.text: And wherefore? Because the pleasure is natural, and the desire of it is innate and of natural growth in the body.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:142
verses.text: It is not so with riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:143
verses.text: Herein we are able to resemble God, in showing mercy and pity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:144
verses.text: When therefore we have not this quality, we are devoid of all good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:145
verses.text: He has not said, "ye shall be like unto your Father, if ye fast," nor "if ye be virgins," nor "if ye pray," hath He said, "ye shall be like unto your Father," for none of these things can be applied to God, nor are they His acts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:146
verses.text: But what? "Be ye merciful, as your Father in Heaven is merciful".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:147
verses.text: (Luke vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:148
verses.text: ) This is the work of God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:149
verses.text: If therefore thou hast not this, what hast thou? He says: "I will have mercy, and not sacrifice".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:150
verses.text: (Hosea vi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:151
verses.text: ) God made Heaven, and earth, and sea.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:152
verses.text: Great works these, and worthy of His wisdom! But by none of these has He so powerfully attracted human nature to Himself, as by mercy and the love of mankind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:153
verses.text: For that indeed is the work of power and wisdom and goodness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:154
verses.text: But it is far more so that He became a servant.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:155
verses.text: Do we not for this more especially admire Him? are we not for this still more amazed at Him? Nothing attracts God to us so much as mercy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:156
verses.text: And the prophets from beginning to end discourse upon this subject.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:157
verses.text: But I speak not of mercy that is accompanied with covetousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:158
verses.text: That is not mercy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:159
verses.text: For it is not the root of the thorn but of the olive that produces the oil; so it is not the root of covetousness, of iniquity, or of rapine, that produces mercy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:160
verses.text: Do not put a slander on almsgiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:161
verses.text: Do not cause it to be evil spoken of by all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:162
verses.text: If thou committest robbery for this, that thou mayest give alms, nothing is more wicked than thy almsgiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:163
verses.text: For when it is produced by rapine, it is not almsgiving, it is inhumanity, it is cruelty, it is an insult to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:164
verses.text: If Cain so offended, by offering inferior gifts of his own, shall he not offend, who offers the goods of another? An offering is nothing else but a sacrifice, a purification, not a pollution.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:165
verses.text: And thou who darest not to pray with unclean hands, dost thou offer the dirt and filth of robbery, and think thou doest nothing wrong? Thou sufferest not thy hands to be full of dirt and filth, but having first cleansed these, thou offerest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:166
verses.text: Yet that filth is no charge against thee, while the other deserves reproach and blame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:167
verses.text: Let it not therefore be our consideration, how we may offer prayers and oblations with clean hands, but how the things offered may be pure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:168
verses.text: If one, after having washed a vessel clean, should fill it with unclean gifts, would it not be ridiculous mockery? Let the hands be clean; and they will be so, if we wash them not with water only, but first with righteousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:169
verses.text: This is the purifier of the hands.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:170
verses.text: But if they be full of unrighteousness, though they be washed a thousand times, it avails nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:171
verses.text: "Wash you, make you clean" (Isa.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:172
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:173
verses.text: ), He says, but does He add, "Go to the baths, the lakes, the rivers"? No; but what? "Put away the evil of your doings from your souls".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:174
verses.text: This is to be clean.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:175
verses.text: This it is to be cleansed from defilement.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:176
verses.text: This is real purity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:177
verses.text: The other is of little use; but this bestows upon us confidence towards God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:178
verses.text: The one may be obtained by adulterers, thieves, murderers, by worthless, and dissolute, and effeminate persons, and especially the latter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:179
verses.text: For they are ever careful of the cleanliness of their bodies, and scented with perfumes, cleansing their sepulcher.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:180
verses.text: For their body is but a sepulcher, since the soul is dead within it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:181
verses.text: This cleanness therefore may be theirs, but not that which is inward.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:182
verses.text: To wash the body is no great matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:183
verses.text: That is a Jewish purification, senseless and unprofitable, where purity within is wanting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:184
verses.text: Suppose one to labor under a putrefying sore, or consuming ulcer; let him wash his body ever so much, it is of no advantage.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:185
verses.text: And if the putrefaction of the body receives no benefit from cleansing and disguising the outward appearance; when the soul is infected with rottenness, what is gained by the purity of the body? Nothing! Our prayers ought to be pure, and pure they cannot be, if they are sent forth from a corrupt soul, and nothing so corrupts the soul as avarice and rapine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:186
verses.text: But there are some who after committing numberless sins during the day, wash themselves in the evening and enter the churches, holding up their hands with much confidence, as if by the washing of the bath they had put off all their guilt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:187
verses.text: And if this were the case, it would be a vast advantage to use the bath daily! I would not myself cease to frequent the baths, if it made us pure, and cleansed us from our sins! But these things are trifling and ridiculous, the toys of children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:188
verses.text: It is not the filth of the body, but the impurity of the soul, to which God is averse.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:189
verses.text: For He says, "Blessed are the pure"does He say in body? No"in heart: for they shall see God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:190
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:191
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:192
verses.text: ) And what says the Prophet: "Create in me a clean heart, O God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:193
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:194
verses.text: li.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:195
verses.text: ) And again, "Wash my heart from wickedness".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:196
verses.text: (Jer.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:197
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:198
verses.text: )  It is of great use to be in the habit of doing good actions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:199
verses.text: See how trifling and unprofitable these washings are.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:200
verses.text: But when the soul is prepossessed by a habit, it does not depart from it, nor does it venture to draw nigh in prayer, till it has fulfilled these ceremonies.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:201
verses.text: For instance, we have brought ourselves to a habit of washing and praying, and without washing we do not think it right to pray.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:202
verses.text: And we do not willingly pray with unwashed hands, as if we should offend God, and violate our conscience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:203
verses.text: Now if this trifling custom has so great power over us, and is observed every day; if we had brought ourselves to a habit of almsgiving, and had determined so constantly to observe it, as never to enter a house of prayer with empty hands, the point would be gained.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:204
verses.text: For great is the power of habit both in good things and in evil, and when this carries us on, there will be little trouble.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:205
verses.text: Many are in the habit of crossing themselves continually, and they need no one to remind them of it, but often when the mind is wandering after other things, the hand is involuntarily drawn by custom, as by some living teacher, to make the sign.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:206
verses.text: Some have brought themselves into a habit of not swearing at all, and therefore neither willingly nor unwillingly do they ever do it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:207
verses.text: Let us then bring ourselves into such a habit of almsgiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:208
verses.text: What labors were it worth to us to discover such a remedy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:209
verses.text: For say, were there not the relief of almsgiving, while we still by our numberless sins rendered ourselves liable to Divine vengeance, should we not have lamented sadly? Should we not have said, O that it were possible by our wealth to wash away our sins, and we would have parted with it all! O that by our riches we could put away the wrath of God, then we would not spare our substance? For if we do this in sickness, and at the point of death we say, "If it were possible to buy off death, such an one would give all his possessions"; much more in this matter.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:210
verses.text: For see how great is the love of God for man.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:211
verses.text: He has granted us power to buy off not temporal but eternal death.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:212
verses.text: Do not purchase, He says, this short life, but that life that is everlasting.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:213
verses.text: It is that I sell thee, not the other: I do not mock thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:214
verses.text: Didst thou gain the present life, thou hadst gained nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:215
verses.text: I know the worth of that which I offer thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:216
verses.text: The bargainers and traffickers in worldly goods do not act thus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:217
verses.text: They, when they can impose on whom they will, give a little to receive a great deal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:218
verses.text: It is not so with God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:219
verses.text: He gives the greater by far for the less.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:220
verses.text: Tell me, if you were to go to a merchant, and he were to set before you two stones, one of little worth, and the other very precious, and sure to fetch a large amount of wealth; if he allowed you for the price of the cheap one to carry off the more costly, should you complain of him? No! You would rather admire his liberality.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:221
verses.text: So now, two lives are set before us, the one temporal, the other eternal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:222
verses.text: These God offers us for sale, but He would sell us the latter rather than the former.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:223
verses.text: Why do we complain, like silly children, that we receive the more precious? Is it possible then to purchase life for money? Yes, when what we bestow is our own, and not the property of another; when we do not practice an imposture.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:224
verses.text: But, you say, henceforth the goods are mine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:225
verses.text: They are not thine after rapine.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:226
verses.text: They are still thy neighbor's, though thou wert a thousand times the master of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:227
verses.text: For if thou shouldest receive a deposit, it would not be thine own even for the short season that the depositor was traveling, though it might be laid up with thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:228
verses.text: If therefore that is not ours, which we received with the consent and thanks of those who deposited it, even for the short period that we retain it, much less is that ours, which we plundered against the will of its owner.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:229
verses.text: He is the master of it, however long thou mayest withhold it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:230
verses.text: But Virtue is really our own; as for money, even our own is not strictly ours, much less that of others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:231
verses.text: Today it is ours, to-morrow it belongs to another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:232
verses.text: What is of virtue is our own possession.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:233
verses.text: This does not suffer loss, like other things, but is entirely possessed by all who have it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 6:234
verses.text: This therefore let us acquire, and let us despise riches, that we may be able to attain those real goods, of which God grant that we may be thought worthy to partake, through the grace and lovingkindness, &c.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:1
verses.text: Homily VII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:2
verses.text: Timothy iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:3
verses.text: "This know also, that in the last days perilous times shall come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:4
verses.text: For men shall be lovers of their own selves, covetous, boasters, proud, blasphemers, disobedient to parents, unthankful, unholy, Without natural affection, truce-breakers, false accusers, incontinent, fierce, despisers of those that are good, Traitors, heady, high-minded, lovers of pleasure more than lovers of God; Having a form of godliness, but denying the power thereof; from such turn away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:5
verses.text: For of this sort are they, which creep into houses, and lead captive silly women laden with sins, led away with divers lusts and pleasures, Ever learning, and never able to come to the knowledge of the truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:6
verses.text: He had said in the former Epistle, that "the Spirit speaketh expressly, that in the latter times some shall depart from the faith" ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:7
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:9
verses.text: ); and elsewhere in this Epistle he foretells that something of this kind will afterwards happen; and here again he does the same thing: "This know, that in the last days perilous times shall come".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:10
verses.text: And this he pronounces not only from the future, but from the past; "As Jannes and Jambres withstood Moses".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:11
verses.text: And again from reasoning; "In a great house there are not only vessels of gold and of silver".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:12
verses.text: But why does he do this? In order that Timothy may not be troubled, nor any one of us, when there are evil men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:13
verses.text: If there were such in the time of Moses, and will be hereafter, it is no wonder that there are such in our times.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:14
verses.text: "In the last days perilous times shall come," he says, that is, exceeding bad times.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:15
verses.text: How shall times be perilous? He says it not blaming the days, nor the times, but the men of those times.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:16
verses.text: For thus it is customary with us to speak of good times or evil times, from the events that happen in them, caused by men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:17
verses.text: Immediately he sets down the root and fountain, whence these and all other evils spring, that is, overweeningness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:18
verses.text: He that is seized with this passion is careless even of his own interests.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:19
verses.text: For when a man overlooks the concerns of his neighbor, and is careless of them, how should he regard his own? For as he that looks to his neighbor's affairs will in them order his own to advantage, so he that looks down upon his neighbor's concerns will neglect his own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:20
verses.text: For if we are members one of another, the welfare of our neighbor is not his concern only, but that of the whole body, and the injury of our neighbor is not confined to him, but distracts with pains all else as well.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:21
verses.text: If we are a building, whatever part is weakened, it affects the whole, whilst that which is solid gives strength and support to the rest.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:22
verses.text: So also in the Church, if thou hast slighted thy neighbor, thou has injured thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:23
verses.text: How? In that one of thy own members hath suffered no small hurt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:24
verses.text: And if he, who does not impart of his possessions, goes into Hell, much more will he be condemned, who sees a neighbor suffering severer evils, and does not stretch out his hand, since in this case the loss is more grievous.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:25
verses.text: "For men shall be lovers of their own selves".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:26
verses.text: He that loves himself may be said not to love himself, but he that loves his brother, loves himself in the truest sense.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:27
verses.text: From self-love springs covetousness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:28
verses.text: For the wretched niggardly temper of self-love contracts that love which should be widely extended, and diffused on every side.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:29
verses.text: "Covetous".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:30
verses.text: From covetousness springs boastfulness, from boastfulness pride, from pride blasphemy, from blasphemy defiance and disobedience.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:31
verses.text: For he who exalts himself against men, will easily do it against God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:32
verses.text: Thus sins are produced.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:33
verses.text: Often they ascend from below.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:34
verses.text: He that is pious towards men, is still more pious towards God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:35
verses.text: He who is meek to his fellow-servants, is more meek to his Master.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:36
verses.text: He that despises his fellow-servants, will end with despising God Himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:37
verses.text: Moral.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:38
verses.text: Let us not then despise one another, for that is an evil training which teaches us to despise God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:39
verses.text: And indeed to despise one another is in effect to despise God, Who commanded us to show all regard to one another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:40
verses.text: And this may be otherwise manifested by an example.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:41
verses.text: Cain despised his brother, and so, immediately after, he despised God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:42
verses.text: How despised Him? Mark his insolent answer to God; "Am I my brother's keeper?" (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:43
verses.text: iv.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:44
verses.text: ) Again, Esau despised his brother, and he too despised God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:45
verses.text: Wherefore God said, "Jacob have I loved, but Esau have I hated".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:46
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:47
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:48
verses.text: ; Mal.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:49
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:51
verses.text: ) Hence Paul says, "Lest there be any fornicator or profane person as Esau".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:52
verses.text: (Heb.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:53
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:54
verses.text: ) The brethren of Joseph despised him, and they also despised God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:55
verses.text: The Israelites despised Moses, and they also despised God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:56
verses.text: So too the sons of Eli despised the people, and they too despised God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:57
verses.text: Would you see it also from the contrary? Abraham, who was tender of his brother's son, was obedient to God, as is manifest in his conduct with respect to his son Isaac, and in all his other virtues.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:58
verses.text: Again, Abel was meek to his brother, and he also was pious towards God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:59
verses.text: Let us not therefore despise one another, lest we learn also to despise God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:60
verses.text: Let us honor one another, that we may learn also to honor God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:61
verses.text: He that is insolent with respect to men, will also be insolent with respect to God.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:62
verses.text: But when covetousness and selfishness and insolence meet together, what is wanting to complete destruction? Everything is corrupted, and a foul flood of sins bursts in.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:63
verses.text: "Unthankful," he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:64
verses.text: For how can the covetous man be thankful? To whom will he feel gratitude? To no one.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:65
verses.text: He considers all men his enemies, and desires the goods of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:66
verses.text: Though you spend your whole substance upon him, he will feel no gratitude.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:67
verses.text: He is angry that you have not more, that you might bestow it upon him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:68
verses.text: And if you made him master of the whole world, he would still be unthankful, and think that he had received nothing.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:69
verses.text: This desire is insatiable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:70
verses.text: It is the craving of disease; and such is the nature of the cravings of disease.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:71
verses.text: He who has a fever can never be satisfied, but with constant desire of drinking, is never filled, but suffers a continual thirst; so he who is mad after wealth never knows the fulfillment of his desire; whatever is bestowed upon him, he is still unsatisfied, and will therefore never be thankful.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:72
verses.text: For he will feel no gratitude to him, who does not give him as much as he wishes, and this no one can ever do.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:73
verses.text: And as there is no limit to his wishes, he will feel no gratitude.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:74
verses.text: Thus no one is so unthankful as the covetous, so insensible as the lover of money.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:75
verses.text: He is the enemy of all the world.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:76
verses.text: He is indignant that there are men.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:77
verses.text: He would have all one vast desert, that he might have the property of all.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:78
verses.text: And many wild imaginations does he form.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:79
verses.text: "O that there were an earthquake," he says, "in the city, that all the rest being swallowed up, I might be left alone, to have, if possible, the possessions of all! O that a pestilence would come and destroy everything but gold! O that there might be a submersion, or an eruption of the sea!" Such are his imaginations.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:80
verses.text: He prays for nothing good, but for earthquakes, and thunderbolts, for wars, and plagues, and the like.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:81
verses.text: Well, tell me now, thou wretched man, more servile than any slave, if all things were gold, wouldest thou not be destroyed by thy gold, and perish with hunger? If the world were swallowed up by an earthquake, thou also wouldest perish by thy fatal desire.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:82
verses.text: For if there were no other men than thyself, the necessaries of life would fail thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:83
verses.text: For suppose that the other inhabitants of the earth were destroyed at once, and that their gold and silver came of its own accord to thee.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:84
verses.text: (For such men fancy to themselves absurdities, and impossibilities.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:85
verses.text: ) But if their gold and silver, their vests of silk and cloth of gold, came into thy hands, what would it profit thee? Death would only the more certainly overtake thee, when there were none to prepare bread or till the earth for thee; wild beasts would prowl around, and the devil agitate thy soul with fear.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:86
verses.text: Many devils indeed now possess it, but then they would lead thee to desperation, and plunge thee at once into destruction.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:87
verses.text: But you say, "I would wish there should be tilling of the land and men to prepare food".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:88
verses.text: Then they would consume somewhat.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:89
verses.text: "But I would not have them consume anything".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:90
verses.text: So insatiable is this desire! For what can be more ridiculous than this? Seest thou the impossibility of the thing? He wishes to have many to minister to him, yet he grudges them their share of food, because it diminishes his substance! What then? Wouldest thou then have men of stone? This is all a mockery; and waves, and tempest, and huge billows, and violent agitation, and storm, overwhelm the soul.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:91
verses.text: It is ever hungry, ever thirsty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:92
verses.text: Shall we not pity and mourn for him? Of bodily diseases this is thought a most painful one, and it is called by physicians bulimy, when a man being filled, is yet always hungry.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:93
verses.text: And is not the same disorder in the soul more lamentable? For avarice is the morbid hunger of the soul, which is always filling, never satisfied, but still craving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:94
verses.text: If it were necessary to drink hellebore, or submit to anything a thousand times worse, would it not be worth our while to undertake it readily, that we might be delivered from this passion? There is no abundance of riches that can fill the belly of greediness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:95
verses.text: And shall we not be ashamed, that men can be thus transported with the love of money, whilst we show not any proportion of such earnestness in love to God, and honor Him not as bullion is honored? For money men will undergo watchings, and journeyings and continual perils, and hatred, and hostility, and, in short, everything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:96
verses.text: But we do not venture to utter a mere word for God, nor incur an enmity, but if we are required to assist any of those who are persecuted, we abandon the injured person, withdrawing ourselves from the hatred of the powerful, and the danger it involves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:97
verses.text: And though God has given us power that we might succor him, yet we suffer him to perish, from our unwillingness to incur men's hatred and displeasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:98
verses.text: And this many profess to justify, saying, "Be loved for nothing, but be not hated for nothing".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:99
verses.text: But is this to be hated for nothing? Or what is better than such hatred? For to be hated on account of God is better than to be loved on His account: for when we are loved for God's sake, we are debtors for the honor, but when we are hated for His sake, He is our debtor to reward us.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:100
verses.text: The lovers of wealth know no limit to their love, be it never so great; but we, if we have done ever so little, think that we have fulfilled everything.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:101
verses.text: We love not God as much, no, not by many times over so much, as they love gold.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:102
verses.text: Their inordinate rage for gold is a heavy accusation against them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:103
verses.text: It is our condemnation that we are not so beside ourselves for God; that we do not bestow upon the Lord of all as much love as they bestow upon mere earth, for gold from the mine is no better.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:104
verses.text: Let us then behold their madness, and be ashamed of ourselves.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:105
verses.text: For what though we are not inflamed with the love of gold, while we are not earnest in our prayers to God? For in their case men despise wife, children, substance, and their own safety, and that when they are not certain that they shall increase their substance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:106
verses.text: For often, in the very midst of their hopes, they lose at once their life and their labor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:107
verses.text: But we, though we know that, if we love Him as we ought to love Him, we shall obtain our desire, yet love Him not, but are altogether cold in our love both to our neighbor and to God; cold in our love to God, because cold in our love to our neighbor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:108
verses.text: For it is not, indeed it is not possible that a man, who is a stranger to the feeling of love, should have any generosity or manly spirit, since the foundation of all that is good is no other than love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:109
verses.text: "On this," it is said, "hang all the law and the prophets".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:110
verses.text: (Matt.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:111
verses.text: xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:112
verses.text: ) For as fire set to a forest is wont to clear away everything, so the fire of love, wherever it is received, consumes and makes way through everything that is hurtful to the divine harvest, and renders the soil pure and fit for the reception of the seed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:113
verses.text: Where there is love, all evils are removed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:114
verses.text: There is no love of money, the root of evil, there is no self-love: there is no boasting; for why should one boast over his friend? Nothing makes a man so humble as love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:115
verses.text: We perform the offices of servants to our friends, and are not ashamed; we are even thankful for the opportunity of serving them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:116
verses.text: We spare not our property, and often not our persons; for dangers too are encountered at times for him that is loved.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:117
verses.text: No envy, no calumny is there, where there is genuine love.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:118
verses.text: We not only do not slander our friends, but we stop the mouth of slanderers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:119
verses.text: All is gentleness and mildness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:120
verses.text: Not a trace of strife and contention appears.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:121
verses.text: Everything breathes peace.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:122
verses.text: For "Love," it is said, "is this fulfilling of the law".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:123
verses.text: (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:124
verses.text: xiii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:125
verses.text: ) There is nothing offensive with it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:126
verses.text: How so? Because where love exists, all the sins of covetousness, rapine, envy, slander, arrogance, perjury, and falsehood are done away.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:127
verses.text: For men perjure themselves, in order to rob, but no one would rob him whom he loved, but would rather give him his own possessions.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:128
verses.text: For we are more obliged than if we received from him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:129
verses.text: Ye know this, all you that have friends, friends, I mean, in reality, not in name only, but whoever loves as men ought to love, whoever is really linked to another.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:130
verses.text: And let those who are ignorant of it learn from those who know.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:131
verses.text: I will now cite you from the Scriptures a wonderful instance of friendship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:132
verses.text: Jonathan, the son of Saul, loved David, and his soul was so knit to him, that David in mourning over him says, "Thy love to me was wonderful, passing the love of women.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:133
verses.text: Thou wast wounded unto death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:134
verses.text: ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:135
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:137
verses.text: ) What then? did he envy David? Not at all, though he had great reason.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:138
verses.text: How? Because, by the events he perceived that the kingdom would pass from himself to him, yet he felt nothing of the kind.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:139
verses.text: He did not say, "This is he that is depriving me of my paternal kingdom," but he favored his obtaining the sovereignty; and he spared not his father for the sake of his friend.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:140
verses.text: Yet let not any one think him a parricide, for he did not injure his father, but restrained his unjust attempts.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:141
verses.text: He rather spared than injured him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:142
verses.text: He did not permit him to proceed to an unjust murder.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:143
verses.text: He was many times willing even to die for his friend, and far from accusing him, he restrained even his father's accusation.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:144
verses.text: Instead of envying, he joined in obtaining the kingdom for him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:145
verses.text: Why do I speak of wealth? He even sacrificed his own life for him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:146
verses.text: For the sake of his friend, he did not even stand in awe of his father, since his father entertained unjust designs, but his conscience was free from all such.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:147
verses.text: Thus justice was conjoined with friendship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:148
verses.text: Such then was Jonathan.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:149
verses.text: Let us now consider David.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:150
verses.text: He had no opportunity of returning the recompense, for his benefactor was taken away before the reign of David, and slain before he whom he had served came to his kingdom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:151
verses.text: What then? As far as it was allowed him and left in his power, let us see how that righteous man manifested his friendship.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:152
verses.text: "Very pleasant," he says, "hast thou been to me, Jonathan; thou wast wounded unto death".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:153
verses.text: ( Sam.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:154
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:155
verses.text: , Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:156
verses.text: ) Is this all? This indeed was no slight tribute, but he also frequently rescued from danger his son and his grandson, in remembrance of the kindness of the father, and he continued to support and protect his children, as he would have done those of his own son.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:157
verses.text: Such friendship I would wish all to entertain both towards the living and the dead.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:158
verses.text: Let women listen to this (for it is on their account especially that I refer to the departed) who enter into a second marriage, and defile the bed of their deceased husband, though they have loved him.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:159
verses.text: Not that I forbid a second marriage, or pronounce it a proof of wantonness, for Paul does not allow me, stopping my mouth by saying to women, "If she marry she hath not sinned".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:160
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:161
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:163
verses.text: ) Yet let us attend to what follows, "But she is happier if she so abide".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:164
verses.text: This state is much better than the other.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:165
verses.text: Wherefore? for many reasons.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:166
verses.text: For if it is better not to marry at all than to marry, much more in this case.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:167
verses.text: "But some, you say, could not endure widowhood, and have fallen into many misfortunes".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:168
verses.text: Yes; because they know not what widowhood is.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:169
verses.text: For it is not widowhood to be exempt from a second marriage, as neither is it virginity to be altogether unmarried.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:170
verses.text: For as "that which is comely," and "that ye may attend upon the Lord without distraction," is the mark of the one state, so it is the mark of the other to be desolate, to "continue in supplications and prayers," to renounce luxury and pleasure.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:171
verses.text: For "she that liveth in pleasure is dead whilst she liveth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:172
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:173
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:174
verses.text: ) If remaining a widow, thou wouldest have the same pomp, the same show, the same attire, as thou hadst while thy husband was living, it were better for thee to marry.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:175
verses.text: For it is not the union that is objectionable, but the multitude of cares that attend it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:176
verses.text: But that which is not wrong, thou dost not: but that which is not indifferent, which is liable to blame, in that thou involvest thyself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:177
verses.text: On this account "some have turned aside after Satan," because they have not been able to live properly as widows.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:178
verses.text: Wouldest thou know what a widow is, and what a widow's dignity, hear Paul's account of it.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:179
verses.text: "If she have brought up children, if she have lodged strangers, if she have washed the Saints' feet, if she have relieved the afflicted, if she have diligently followed every good work".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:180
verses.text: ( Tim.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:181
verses.text: v.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:182
verses.text: ) But when after the death of thy husband, thou art arrayed in the same pomp of wealth, no wonder if thou canst not support widowhood.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:183
verses.text: Transfer this wealth, therefore, to heaven, and thou wilt find the burden of widowhood tolerable.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:184
verses.text: But, thou sayest, what if I have children to succeed to their father's inheritance? Instruct them also to despise riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:185
verses.text: Transfer thy own possessions, reserving for them just a sufficiency.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:186
verses.text: Teach them too to be superior to riches.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:187
verses.text: But what if besides my silver and gold, I am surrounded by a crowd of slaves, oppressed by a multitude of affairs, how shall I be equal to the care of all these things, when deprived of the support of my husband? This is but an excuse, a pretense, as appears from many causes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:188
verses.text: For if thou dost not deserve wealth, nor seek to increase thy present possessions, thy burden will be light.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:189
verses.text: To get riches is much more laborious than to take care of them.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:190
verses.text: If therefore thou cuttest off this one thing, accumulating, and suppliest the needy out of thy substance, God will hold over thee His protecting hand.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:191
verses.text: And if thou sayest this from a real desire to preserve the inheritance of thy fatherless children, and art not, under this pretense, possessed with covetousness; He who searches the heart knows how to secure their riches, even He who commanded thee to bring up children.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:192
verses.text: For it is not possible, indeed it is not, that a house established by almsgiving should suffer any calamity.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:193
verses.text: If it should be unfortunate for a time, in the end it will prosper.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:194
verses.text: This will be more than spear and shield to all the household.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:195
verses.text: Hear what the devil says concerning Job.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:196
verses.text: "Hast not thou made an hedge about him and about his house, and about all that he hath on every side?" (Job i.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:197
verses.text: ) Wherefore? Hear Job himself saying, "I was eyes to the blind, and feet was I to the lame.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:198
verses.text: I was a father to the orphans".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:199
verses.text: (Job xxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:200
verses.text: ) As he who does not turn aside from the calamities of others, will not suffer even in his own misfortunes, because he has learnt to sympathize; so he who will not bear the griefs of sympathy, will learn all sorrow in his own person.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:201
verses.text: And, as in the case of a bodily disease, if, when the foot is mortified, the hand does not sympathize by cleansing the wound, washing away the discharge, and applying a plaster, it will suffer the like disease of its own; so she who will not minister to another when she is not herself afflicted, will have to bear sufferings of her own.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:202
verses.text: For the evil spreading from the other part will reach to this also, and the question will not be of ministering to the other, but of its own cure and relief.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:203
verses.text: So it is here also.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:204
verses.text: He that will not relieve others, will be a sufferer himself.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:205
verses.text: "Thou hast hedged him in," saith Satan, "within and without," and I dare not attack him! But he suffered afflictions, you say.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:206
verses.text: True.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:207
verses.text: But those afflictions were the occasion of great good.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:208
verses.text: His substance was doubled, his reward increased, his righteousness enlarged, his crown was splendid, his prize glorious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:209
verses.text: Both his spiritual and temporal blessings were augmented.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:210
verses.text: He lost his children, but he received, not these restored, but others in their room, and those too he had safe for the Resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:211
verses.text: Had they been restored, the number would have been diminished, but now having given others in their stead, He will present them also at the Resurrection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:212
verses.text: All these things happened to him, because of his openhandedness in almsgiving.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 7:213
verses.text: Let us then do likewise, that we may obtain the same rewards by the grace and lovingkindness of our Lord Jesus Christ, Amen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:1
verses.text: Homily VIII.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:2
verses.text: Timothy iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:3
verses.text: "This know also, that in the last days perilous times shall come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:4
verses.text: For men shall be lovers of their own selves, covetous, boasters, proud, blasphemers, disobedient to parents, unthankful, unholy, without natural affection, truce-breakers, false accusers, incontinent, fierce, despisers of those that are good, Traitors, heady, high-minded, lovers of pleasures more than lovers of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:5
verses.text: If any now takes offense at the existence of heretics, let him remember that it was so from the beginning, the devil always setting up error by the side of truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:6
verses.text: God from the beginning promised good, the devil came too with a promise.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:7
verses.text: God planted Paradise, the devil deceived, saying, "Ye shall be as gods".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:8
verses.text: (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:9
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:10
verses.text: ) For as he could show nothing in actions, he made the more promises in words.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:11
verses.text: Such is the character of deceivers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:12
verses.text: After this were Cain and Abel, then the sons of Seth and the daughters of men; afterwards Ham and Japhet, Abraham and Pharaoh, Jacob and Esau; and so it is even to the end, Moses and the magicians, the Prophets and the false prophets, the Apostles and the false apostles, Christ and Antichrist.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:13
verses.text: Thus it was then, both before and at that time.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:14
verses.text: Then there was Theudas, then Simon, then were the Apostles, then too this party of Hermogenes and Philetus.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:15
verses.text: In short, there was no time when falsehood was not set up in opposition to truth.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:16
verses.text: Let us not therefore be distressed.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:17
verses.text: That it would be so, was foretold from the beginning.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:18
verses.text: Therefore he says, "Know that in the last days perilous times shall come.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:19
verses.text: For men shall be lovers of their own selves, covetous, boasters, proud, blasphemers, disobedient to parents, unthankful, unholy, without natural affection".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:20
verses.text: The unthankful then is unholy, and this is natural, for what will he be to others, who is not grateful to his benefactor? The unthankful man is a truce-breaker, he is without natural affection.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:21
verses.text: "False accusers," that is, slanderers.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:22
verses.text: For those who are conscious that they have no good in themselves, whilst they commit many sins and offenses, find consolation in defaming the characters of others.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:23
verses.text: "Incontinent," with respect both to their tongue and their appetite, and everything else.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:24
verses.text: "Fierce," hence their inhumanity and cruelty, when any one is covetous, selfish, ungrateful, licentious.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:25
verses.text: "Despisers of those that are good, traitors, heady".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:26
verses.text: "Traitors," betrayers of friendship; "heady," having no steadiness; "high-minded," filled with arrogance.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:27
verses.text: "Lovers of pleasures more than lovers of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:28
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:29
verses.text: "Having a form of godliness, but denying the power thereof".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:30
verses.text: In the Epistle to the Romans, he says somewhat on this wise, "Having the form of knowledge and of the truth in the law" (Rom.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:31
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:32
verses.text: ), where he speaks in commendation of it: but here he speaks of this sin as an evil beyond all other defects.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:33
verses.text: And why is this? Because he does not use the words in the same signification.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:34
verses.text: For an image is often taken to signify a likeness; but sometimes a thing without life, and worthless.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:35
verses.text: Thus he says himself in his Epistle to the Corinthians, "A man ought not to cover his head, forasmuch as he is the image and glory of God".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:36
verses.text: ( Cor.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:37
verses.text: xi.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:38
verses.text: ) But the Prophet says, "Man walketh in an image".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:39
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:40
verses.text: xxxix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:41
verses.text: , Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:42
verses.text: ) And the Scripture sometimes takes a lion to represent royalty, as, "He couched as a lion, and as a lion's whelp, who shall raise him up?" (Gen.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:43
verses.text: xlix.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:44
verses.text: , Gr.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:45
verses.text: ) And sometimes to signify rapacity, as, "a ravening and a roaring lion".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:46
verses.text: (Ps.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:47
verses.text: xxii.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:48
verses.text: ) And we ourselves do the same.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:49
verses.text: For as things are compounded and varied in themselves, they are fitly adduced for various images and examples.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:50
verses.text: As when we would express our admiration of a beautiful woman, we say, she is like a picture; and when we admire a painting, we say that it speaks, that it breathes.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:51
verses.text: But we do not mean to express the same thing, but in one case to mark likeness, in the other beauty.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:52
verses.text: So here with respect to form, in the one passage, it means a model, or representation, a doctrine, or pattern of godliness; in the other, something that is lifeless, a mere appearance, show, and hypocrisy.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:53
verses.text: Faith therefore, without works, is fitly called a mere form without the power.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:54
verses.text: For as a fair and florid body, when it has no strength, is like a painted figure, so is a right faith apart from works.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:55
verses.text: For let us suppose any one to be "covetous, a traitor, heady," and yet to believe aright; of what advantage is it, if he wants all the qualities becoming a Christian, if he does not the works that characterize godliness, but outdoes the Greeks in impiety, when he is a mischief to those with whom he associates, causes God to be blasphemed, and the doctrine to be slandered by his evil deeds?  "From such turn away," he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:56
verses.text: But how is this, if men are to be so "in the latter times"? There were probably then such, in some degree at least, though not to the same excess.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:57
verses.text: But, in truth, through him he warns all to turn away from such characters.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:58
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:59
verses.text: "For of this sort are they which creep into houses, and lead captive silly women laden with sins, led away with divers lust".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:60
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:61
verses.text: "Ever learning, and never able to come to the knowledge of the truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:62
verses.text: Do you see them employing the artifice of that old deceiver, the weapons which the devil used against Adam? "Entering into houses," he says.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:63
verses.text: Observe how he shows their impudence by this expression, their dishonorable ways, their deceitfulness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:64
verses.text: "Leading captive silly women," so that he who is easy to be deceived is a "silly woman," and nothing like a man: for to be deceived is the part of silly women.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:65
verses.text: "Laden with sins".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:66
verses.text: See whence arises their persuasion, from their sins, from their being conscious to themselves of nothing good! And with great propriety has he said "laden".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:67
verses.text: For this expression marks the multitude of their sins, and their state of disorder and confusion; "led away with divers lusts".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:68
verses.text: He does not accuse nature, for it is not women simply, but such women as these, that he blames.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:69
verses.text: And why "divers lusts"? by that are implied their various faults, their luxury, their disorderly conduct, their wantonness.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:70
verses.text: "Divers lust," he says, that is, of glory, of wealth, of pleasure, of self-will, of honor: and perchance other vile desires are implied.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:71
verses.text: "Ever learning, and never able to come to the knowledge of the truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:72
verses.text: He does not say thus to excuse, but to threaten them severely; for their understanding was callous, because they had weighed themselves down with lusts and sins.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:73
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:74
verses.text: "Now as Jannes and Jambres withstood Moses, so do these also resist the truth".

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:75
verses.text: Who are these? The magicians in the time of Moses.

verses.name: Chrysostom: On 2 Timothy 8:76
